title: Prince William, Duchess Kate ended Pakistan tour with puppies
text:
Duchess Kate visits an Army Canine Centre with Prince William on October 18, 2019 in Islamabad, Pakistan. (Photo: Pool/Samir Hussein, WireImage)

After their Thursday ended with a lightning storm that affected their travel, Prince William and Duchess Kate's fifth and final day in Pakistan started on a much happier note – with puppies.

The royal couple visited an Army Canine Centre in Islamabad, where the UK provides support to a program that trains dogs to identify explosives.

According to People and Town & Country magazine, Will and Kate had the chance to take yellow Labrador puppies called Sky and Salto on an agility course.

The couple is known to like dogs. They added Cocker Spaniel Lupo to their family before they welcomed their three children: Prince George, 6, Princess Charlotte, 4 or Prince Louis, 1.

More: Duchess Kate channels Princess Diana during Pakistan tour with similar styles

More: Prince William and Duchess Kate arrive in Pakistan for their 'most complex tour' ever

Duchess Kate and Prince William in Pakistan. (Photo: Pool/Samir Hussein, WireImage)

The Cambridge's fourth day of their Pakistan tour started with cricket and visits to an orphanage and to an historic mosque in Lahore before a lightning storm prevented their plane from returning to Islamabad late Thursday.

The royal couple, traveling on an RAF Voyager jet, departed Lahore, the country's "city of culture," according to Kensington Palace, in the evening but ran into a fierce storm as it tried to land in Islamabad, where they had been staying since they arrived for a five-day visit on Monday.

"It was pretty bumpy up there," the duchess said Friday to reporters, according to People and the Belfast Telegraph. "We were looked after so wonderfully by the RAF who did a great job liaising with everyone and got us home safely."

She also said she was "hugely grateful" for the jet staff, per the outlets.

"At one point, lightning could be seen over the right wing as the plane bumped and rolled side to side over stormy Islamabad," reported People magazine, which had a journalist on the plane.

The royals' five-day official visit was described as their "most complex" ever due to major logistical and security issues in a diplomatically touchy region.

Contributing: Maria Puente, Erin Jensen

description: Prince William and Duchess Kate's fifth and final day in Pakistan started on a happy note – with puppies.
